G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: G.L. c. 186, § 14 provides, in relevant part, that a landlord “shall not… directly or indirectly interfere with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant.”

G.L. c. 239.proposition: Venue is proper in the Worcester District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 239 and G.L. c. 223 because the Premises is located in Worcester, Massachusetts, within this Court’s territorial jurisdiction, and the acts and omissions complained of occurred in this county.

G.L. c. 223.proposition: Venue is proper in the Worcester District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 239 and G.L. c. 223 because the Premises is located in Worcester, Massachusetts, within this Court’s territorial jurisdiction, and the acts and omissions complained of occurred in this county.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and related provisions governing civil actions within the jurisdictional limits of the District Court.

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7\u00a7 127A\u2013127L.proposition: As the owner and landlord of the Premises, Defendant is responsible for complying with the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code and maintaining the Premises in compliance with G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L and 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., including the duty to ensure that the Premises is free from rodent infestation.

105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq..proposition: As the owner and landlord of the Premises, Defendant is responsible for complying with the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code and maintaining the Premises in compliance with G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L and 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., including the duty to ensure that the Premises is free from rodent infestation.

105 C.M.R. 410.550.proposition: Under 105 C.M.R. 410.550 and related provisions, an owner is required to maintain the dwelling free from rodent infestation and to take all reasonable measures to exterminate rodents whenever conditions indicate such infestation.

Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.raw_text: Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973).
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.proposition: Defendant’s failure and refusal to correct the rodent infestation, after notice and over an extended period, has rendered the Premises in violation of the State Sanitary Code and unfit for human habitation within the meaning of Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973).
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.support_reasoning: The quoted portion is Justice Quirico’s separate concurrence/dissent and is focused on the doctrinal question of an implied warranty of habitability and the role of the State Sanitary Code generally. It does not involve or discuss rodent infestation specifically, nor does it set out a rule that a landlord’s failure to correct such an infestation, after notice, renders premises unfit for human habitation. While the case is foundational for tying code violations to habitability, this passage does not clearly support the specific proposition about rodent infestation rendering the premises unfit within the meaning of Hemingway.
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.relevant_excerpt: “Since 1960 dwelling units have been subject to the State Sanitary Code… It expressly provides that ‘[n]o person shall … let to another for occupancy any dwelling, dwelling unit, or rooming unit… which does not comply’ with its provisions… The Code… fixes minimum standards of fitness of structures for human habitation… The net result of this court’s interpretation of these statutes was (a) that the owner of a dwelling unit which did not comply with the prescribed minimum standards could be prosecuted criminally…”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with the use, occupancy, and enjoyment of the leased premises. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102–03 (1982); Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715–17 (1977).
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly defines “quiet enjoyment” in terms that match the proposition, describing it as the tenant’s right to be free from serious interferences that impair the character and value of the leased premises. In its discussion of the common-law covenant and of G.L. c. 186, § 14, the court adopts this understanding as the governing standard, so the case directly supports the stated principle about the scope of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33, 36 (1929) (quoting from Brande v. Grace, 154 Mass. 210, 212 [1891]). See Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977). Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy.”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715\.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with the use, occupancy, and enjoyment of the leased premises. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102–03 (1982); Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715–17 (1977).
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715\.support_reasoning: The opinion directly concerns the covenant of quiet enjoyment and a constructive eviction based on substantial interference with tenants’ use and occupancy caused by loud late‑night noise. The court affirms that a breach of the implied covenant occurs when the landlord’s conduct or permitted conditions naturally and probably deprive tenants of the beneficial enjoyment of their premises, even without an intent to evict. This aligns with the proposition that quiet enjoyment protects freedom from serious interference with use, occupancy, and enjoyment of the leased premises.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715\.relevant_excerpt: “The judge found that the tenants were ‘very substantially deprived’ of quiet enjoyment of their leased premises ‘for a substantial time.’ He ruled that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated by late evening and early morning music and disturbances… There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 283–85 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landlord may breach the covenant of quiet enjoyment by permitting or failing to remedy conditions that materially interfere with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises, especially conditions affecting health and safety. See Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 283–85 (1994); Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982, 983 (1982) (rescript).
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion directly holds that the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 protects tenants from serious interferences with their tenancies caused by what the landlord does, fails to do, or permits to be done. The court explains that if the landlord fails to take available measures to remove persons engaged in unlawful activity whose presence seriously interferes with tenants’ use of common areas, this may constitute a breach. The case thus supports the proposition that a landlord may breach quiet enjoyment by permitting or failing to remedy conditions that materially interfere with tenants’ use and enjoyment, particularly where health and safety are implicated.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold… a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’ … if the defendant has failed to take any measures… to remove unwelcome persons… and the presence of those persons seriously interferes with the tenancy, then the defendant may be liable for a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982, 983 (1982) (rescript)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landlord may breach the covenant of quiet enjoyment by permitting or failing to remedy conditions that materially interfere with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises, especially conditions affecting health and safety. See Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 283–85 (1994); Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982, 983 (1982) (rescript).
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that a landlord’s failure to provide heat—a condition directly affecting health and safety and materially impairing the character and value of the premises—constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. The court rejects any defense based on the landlord’s financial inability and emphasizes that liability turns on the natural and probable consequences of the landlord’s conduct, not intent, thereby supporting the broader proposition that allowing such serious conditions to persist can breach quiet enjoyment.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season…seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’…and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.… Thus, as suggested by the language of the statute itself…liability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’… On the facts found by the judge, the tenant was entitled on the quiet enjoyment claim to (a) a declaration that the landlords had violated G. L. c. 186, § 14….”

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 200–02 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: A landlord’s failure to correct known violations of the State Sanitary Code, after notice, may constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment. See Simon, 385 Mass. at 102–05; Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 200–02 (1979).
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The case discusses State Sanitary Code violations only in the context of the implied warranty of habitability and rent abatement, not in connection with a statutory or common-law claim for breach of quiet enjoyment. The court’s holding is that a landlord’s duty under the warranty of habitability is strict and that rent abates once the landlord has notice of noncompliance with the Sanitary Code; it does not analyze or hold that failure to correct known Sanitary Code violations constitutes a breach of quiet enjoyment. Thus, the opinion does not support the specific quiet-enjoyment proposition for which it is cited.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “A dwelling afflicted with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable. The essential objective of the warranty is to make sure that the tenant receives what she is paying for. The tenant may not excuse her obligation with mere reasonable efforts to pay rent. Nor may the landlord avoid his duty with mere reasonable efforts to provide a habitable dwelling. … The Code puts the landlord on notice that it must supply adequate heat and hot water.”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that a landlord’s intentional or reckless failure to correct serious defects or code violations after notice can amount to a “direct or indirect” interference with quiet enjoyment within the meaning of G.L. c. 186, § 14. See Simon, 385 Mass. at 102–05; Doe, 417 Mass. at 283–85; Lowery, 13 Mass. App. Ct. at 983; Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850–51 (1997).
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.support_reasoning: The opinion directly addresses the standard for liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and holds that at least negligent (i.e., fault-based) conduct by a landlord is required, explicitly noting that a landlord’s failure to repair known defects has repeatedly been treated as violating § 14. While the case’s specific context is lead paint, the Court reaffirms that when a landlord has notice or reason to know of a hazardous condition and fails to take appropriate corrective measures, that conduct can constitute an actionable interference with quiet enjoyment. This fits the proposition that intentional or reckless failure to correct serious defects after notice can amount to a “direct or indirect” interference with quiet enjoyment.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.relevant_excerpt: “We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’ See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon… Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord… Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.”

McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304 (.raw_text: McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304 (1977)
McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304 (.proposition: Additional authorities on habitability and landlord obligations, including but not limited to: McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304 (1977) (connection between code violations and breach of landlord’s obligations); Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782 (1994) (reaffirming tenant protections under Massachusetts landlord-tenant law).
McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304 (.support_reasoning: The opinion directly links State Sanitary Code violations to breach of the implied warranty of habitability and explains the landlord’s obligation to let and maintain premises in habitable condition. It further clarifies when code violations (including in common areas) can give rise to damages and rejects treating the agreed rent as reflecting acceptance of substandard conditions, reinforcing that such violations are actionable breaches of the landlord’s obligations. Thus, it properly serves as an additional authority on habitability and landlord obligations, specifically the connection between code violations and breach.
McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304 (.relevant_excerpt: “This case returns to us…for computation…of the damages owed to a tenant by his landlord for breach of the implied warranty of habitability… the judge had awarded damages…for violations of the State Sanitary Code… We…held that the rent agreed upon could not be taken…as the rental value of the premises in a defective condition but as the rental value of the premises as warranted to be habitable. Under the formula applied by the judge, rental of defective premises would be tantamount to a waiver of the landlord’s implied obligation to let and maintain the premises in a habitable condition….”

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782.proposition: Additional authorities on habitability and landlord obligations, including but not limited to: McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304 (1977) (connection between code violations and breach of landlord’s obligations); Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782 (1994) (reaffirming tenant protections under Massachusetts landlord-tenant law).
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782.support_reasoning: The opinion directly concerns habitability and landlord obligations: it affirms a substantial breach of the implied warranty of habitability for serious code violations, clarifies how damages are calculated in such cases (including for subsidized tenancies), and holds that negligent failures to repair known code violations can constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment and an unfair practice under c. 93A. In doing so, it clearly reinforces and expands tenant protections under Massachusetts landlord‑tenant law, consistent with the proposition for which it is cited.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782.relevant_excerpt: “From May, 1988, through October, 1990 … conditions in the apartment violated numerous provisions of the State Sanitary Code… The judge found that conditions during the relevant period ‘were such so as to make the premises of no value to [Thomas].’… Thomas was entitled to damages calculated on the basis of value of the premises as warranted… A landlord’s failure to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14…. On the facts found by the judge a violation of § 14 has been shown.”
